title: Suggestion list for launch.json is inaccurate in some cases
body:
@karrtikr commented on [Wed Sep 25 2019](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-python/issues/7612)

<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

## Environment data

- VS Code version: 1.38.1
- Extension version (available under the Extensions sidebar): 2019.10.38352-dev
- OS and version: Windows

## Expected behaviour

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13199757/65645901-10c28d80-dfae-11e9-8791-de0015478e5a.png)


## Actual behaviour

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13199757/65645867-f7b9dc80-dfad-11e9-8ed4-dc88d57933e3.png)

When pressing `CTRL + SPACE` to pop up suggestions after the very last curly bracket, it shows the wrong things in the list.

cc @luabud 



---

@luabud commented on [Wed Sep 25 2019](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-python/issues/7612#issuecomment-535274542)

I can repro it with 2019.8.29288. I think this is reason-preexisting 

---

@karrtikr commented on [Wed Sep 25 2019](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-python/issues/7612#issuecomment-535275520)

It worked before AFAIC recall. This maybe upstream VSCode issue which is why you're able to repro it with the older versions.

---

@DonJayamanne commented on [Wed Sep 25 2019](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-python/issues/7612#issuecomment-535341943)

Isn't this an upstream issue?

title: Untangle titlebar dependency from activity bar
body:
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/commit/d49dad0e9a2f5ea141536c9b81989dbf0d1a9762 adds a dependency from activity bar to the title bar for adding the compact menu option.

Rather, I think the activity bar should expose a dynamic menu that can be contributed to, possibly the same menu point we use in the title, so that we just have another location for the main menu.

title: Add paste option on right click for terminal
body:
Resolves #81447.

There are two main ways to implement this I think:

A. Slightly modify the already existing `copyPaste` (this is how it is done now).
B. Add an else-if to support the new feature (which would just be terminal.paste())

The reason I went for option A is because of the fix for Macs as that would probably need to be duplicated. I haven't tested this PR on Mac, only Win10.

title: Feature: paste on right click regardless of selection
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
With #38287 being merged, I'd now like to be able to directly paste after selection.

The current behaviour with copyOnSelection = true and rightClickBehavior = copyPaste:

1. select text (text is then copied into clipboard)
2. right or left click, this clears the selection
3. right click again to paste

With the proposed mode, copyOnSelection = true and rightClickBehavior = paste:

1. select text (text is then copied into clipboard)
2. right click, and text is pasted

Why do I want this? Simple: it removes an extra click when pasting.
This mirrors how PuTTY's pastes. The new Windows Terminal recently got support for this feature, too - https://github.com/microsoft/terminal/pull/2152

title: Change multi line text search shortcut from ctrl+enter to shift+enter
body:
In the latest update  (2019/09/25), the new multi line search feature was introduced, but the shortcut isn't the same as in every other app **where pressing the enter key sends the message**

For example in slack to create a new line you hold shift and press enter
Same thing in facebook messenger, whatsapp, steam, real time support chats (e.g. amazon), etc

I think VScode should follow the "standard" and change the key combination from ctrl+enter to shift+enter, to be in line with every other app

title: Investigate to support MS build of Electron when running out of sources
body: I find we should revisit our decision to not use the same build we have in production when running out of sources. To catch every issue we should ensure that the same build is being used.

title: SerializeRequest should throw if an argument can not be serialized
body:
Currently the [`seriazlieRequest`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/74731f65aa82e69c28e75a29a0fee7348dd6befa/src/vs/workbench/services/extensions/common/rpcProtocol.ts#L595) does not throw if the argument can not be serialized, it simply converts all the arguments to `null` [here](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/74731f65aa82e69c28e75a29a0fee7348dd6befa/src/vs/workbench/services/extensions/common/rpcProtocol.ts#L26)

Just throwing an error is better than a no-op which makes it hard to discover the issue.
Is there some particular reason why we do not throw here?

fyi @alexandrudima @bpasero

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.38.1
- OS Version: Windows (others?)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use the C/C++ extension to attach to a multithreaded process, break into the debugger, and right click a call stack and choose "Copy Call Stack" and then paste somewhere.

Bug: Copy silently has no effect. It works with TypeScript debugging. I don't think our C/C++ debugger extension is to blame.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: Auto import not working
Process debug adapter messages in separate tasks; see #33822, #79196
On non-Windows, the debug command line expects a `sh` compliant shell
body:
- VSCode Version: 1.38.1
- OS Version: macOS 18.7.0

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install PowerShell 7 Preview 4
2. chsh your default shell to pwsh-preview
3. try to debug in VSCode

VSCode uses a command line like:

```
cd '/Users/steve/.vscode/extensions/ms-vscode.csharp-1.21.3/.debugger/';  '/Users/steve/.vscode/extensions/ms-vscode.csharp-1.21.3/.debugger/vsdbg' '--interpreter=vscode' '--connection=/var/folders/1h/96n_hpk92332gjn6pcz0mvxr0000gn/T/CoreFxPipe_vsdbg-ui-452b151b0eb847fba759ea7337b5af33'
```

The problem is when using PowerShell as the default shell, the `vsdbg` command being in single quotes is treated as a string so that command fails.  Since `cd` is already used to go to that location, there's no need to have the full path to `vsdbg`, if this command line was changed to:

cd '/Users/steve/.vscode/extensions/ms-vscode.csharp-1.21.3/.debugger/';  ./vsdbg '--interpreter=vscode' '--connection=/var/folders/1h/96n_hpk92332gjn6pcz0mvxr0000gn/T/CoreFxPipe_vsdbg-ui-452b151b0eb847fba759ea7337b5af33'

Then it would continue to work with sh, bash, etc... and would also work with PowerShell since it's already changing to working directory to the location of the debugger.

title: git: Initial support for filters declared in .gitattributes
body:
This is an initial implementation for issue #24883.

**Rationale**

We use [git-crypt](https://github.com/AGWA/git-crypt) to ensure that some propriety code is kept secure. This generally works well but can cause issues with Git functionality in other tools. We use VS Code for development and it's a pain to not have the integrated diff functionality when reviewing changes of encrypted files.

**Current Situation**

The `.gitattributes` file is modified to add the necessary [filter](https://git-scm.com/docs/gitattributes) attribute (amongst others) so git works as expected when checking out, merging etc. Lots of other tools will set attributes as well.

As a result, the basic git commands will work in VS Code but not the diff functionality due to the way the extension uses git show to obtain the file content which bypasses any settings in `.gitattributes`. 

Currently a user will receive the following message:

> The file is not displayed in the editor because it is either binary or uses an unsupported text encoding

Although our use case is for git-crypt specifically, this issue affects any tool that relies on `.gitattributes` being properly supported. We have focused on the `filter` attribute only as this is the only attribute we have discovered a need to support at present.

**Overall Approach**

All changes occur in the git extension (`extensions/git`)

1. *No breaking API changes*. All changes are accomplished via addition of optional parameters so existing functionality will be unaffected. The external extension API interface in `src/api/api1.ts` has deliberately not been modified at present. Once the implementation has been validated and tested then consideration should be given to whether this should be updated. 

2. Support has been added to call [git check-attr](https://git-scm.com/docs/git-check-attr) to check relevant file paths for a `filter` attribute. This is exposed via `getGitFilter`.

3. Git URIs have been modified to support an extra `filter` parameter to indicate if a filter is required to be used to obtain the content of a git object. 

4. `getURI` in `commands.ts` has been modified to check the filter defined (if any) for a given path. If a filter is set, this is passed to `detectObjectType` so it can detect the correct encoding of the content by passing through filter. It is also added to the URI.

5. The `show` in `repository.ts` now takes the optional filter parameter (as provided by URI). This will be cause content to be piped through the filter prior to being returned.

**Some Future Considerations**

1. Would it ever be worthwhile to add a configuration option to skip filter checking in `getURI`?
2. May require further improvements to check for the filter attributes using `.gitattributes` as per the relevant Git reference instead of `HEAD`. However, current functionality is very useful and support for this use case can be added later.
3. Requires use of `shell` option when spawning child process for `git show` so output can be piped to filter (which is in an unknown location). Although there is a possibly security risk here this is arguably not any greater than the user using relevant git commands which will in essence perform the same activity. However, need to ensure this works on all supported platforms and confirm this rationale.

title: HTML reindent lines with enters in table data cells cause staircase effect
body:
Issue Type: Bug When using enters in table data cells, the next tags will be indented one indent too far when using reindent lines from the command palette, causing a ripple effect with a lovely table staircase. Example: ```html
Task Text Text
Text More Text Text
``` Add an enter between More and Text, select `Reindent lines` and watch the staircase effect happen. Remove the enter, select `Reindent lines` and the indentation is as you would expect. title: Typescript errors disappear from typescript file when file is opened
body:
Problem:

vscode will not display some typescript errors inline.  With source files closed if you compile the project it finds errors as expected and shows them in the task window.  It also reports them in the 'problems' tab of the console.  As soon as you open the file, certain problems gets dropped from the 'problems' tab and the editor shows no error.  
![errormissing](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3734797/65541656-febbee80-deca-11e9-8c41-6ff9feea7420.png)

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Compile or compile and watch a typescript program.  There are a whole class of errors which do not show up.  This code demonstrates it 
```
class test {
}
test[1] 
```
2.  The error shows up in the compile window and the problem window.
3.  Open up the source file:  the problem disappears from the problem window and does not show up inline in the editor.

System:
This error occurs on current release and on the latest insider release with no extentions.  I have reproduced it with empty settings files.

Version: 1.39.0-insider (system setup)
Date: 2019-09-24T05:26:22.699Z
Electron: 6.0.9
Chrome: 76.0.3809.146
Node.js: 12.4.0
V8: 7.6.303.31-electron.0
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.18362

title: Unified remote port forwarding UX
body:
## Problem
Remote extensions current each implement their own version of port forwarding, including their own configuration and UI related to port forwarding (see the ssh and containers extensions for example). Even with just two extensions supporting port forwarding, the UX around port forwarding is not consistent and we have duplicated development effort. This problem will  become worse as more extensions / scenarios add support for port forwarding

Additionally, VS Code has a built-in tunneling mechanism that can be used to implement a limited version of port forwarding even if the remote extension doesn't directly support it. There is currently no UI for managing these tunnels. Managing these will become important if we allow extensions to open new tunnels, as #81131 proposes

## Proposal
Build a unified port forwarding user experience that the remote extensions can contribute to. This would act somewhat like the existing `Remote Explorer` contribution

**High level UX Needs**
- List ports currently being forwarded
    - Include human readable names
    - Maybe include type (through VS Code's built-in tunnel service, through remote, external, ...)
- Let user close one of these ports
- Let user open a new port forwarding

**High level extension API needs**
- A way for VS Code to call out to the remote extension to create a new port forwarding. We also need to be able to tear down this connection (probably just make the result of the api call disposable)
- A way for a remote extension to tell us about port forwardings managed outside of VS Code (see [ssh's `LocalFoward` support](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/remote/ssh#_always-forwarding-a-port) for an example of this)
    - We likely also need a way so that the extension can signal that its external port forwardings have changed
- Possible: provide a list of candidate ports for forwarding but that require user action to establish? (see the [containers port forwarding ux](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/remote/containers#_temporarily-forwarding-a-port) for an example of this)




/cc @Chuxel for general feedback, @roblourens and @kieferrm for ssh, and @chrmarti for containers

```bash
$ snap info code
name:      code
summary:   Code editing. Redefined.
publisher: Visual Studio Code (vscode✓)

license:   unset
description: |
  Visual Studio Code is a lightweight but powerful source code editor which runs on your desktop and

```

So, the installed version is quite cryptic without looking at the commit b37e54c9 and would be nice to have an human-readable version in the snap info.

title: Limited space to select the first position in a line

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Version: 1.38.1 (user setup)
Commit: b37e54c98e1a74ba89e03073e5a3761284e3ffb0
Date: 2019-09-11T13:35:15.005Z
Electron: 4.2.10
Chrome: 69.0.3497.128
Node.js: 10.11.0
V8: 6.9.427.31-electron.0
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.17763

Steps to Reproduce:

On any line with text, attempt to use the mouse to place the cursor at the beginning of the line, before the first character. The amount of space is so small, it's difficult to get to the first position. Depending on where the mouse is located, you actually can see the mouse change to the text icon, but are unable to click before the first character. The mouse has to be entirely over the first character to get the cursor to the location prior to the first character. 

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: Import external fonts

**Feature Request**
I would like to be able to import external hosted fonts and use these in VS Code.

**Background Information**
I'm using a system with restricted permission rights so it doesn't let me install new fonts.

title: quick diff gutter not fully working with Multiple different SCM Providers (git, svn...)
body: Issue Type: Bug Hi, Having a folder or a workspace with 2 svn subfolders and 2 git subfolder, quick diff are only displayed for the first SCM control provider initialized. In this example, if svn source control provider is initialized first then quick diff are only displayed for modified svn files. Inversely, if git source control provider is initialized first then quick diff is displayed only for git modified files. In this example I take 2 repositories for both scm to show that if you have git repositories only or svn repositories only, you will not have the issue. Hope explanations are clear, otherwise feel free to ask me details on this issue. thanks. VS Code version: Code 1.38.1 (b37e54c98e1a74ba89e03073e5a3761284e3ffb0, 2019-09-11T13:35:15.005Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10

title: Custom title: move into electron-browser namespace

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body:
In order to properly separate methods that can only be used from `electron-browser` and not `browser`, we need to move them to a place that is only accessible by `electron-browser`.

Currently a lot of window related methods are used within `titlebarPart.ts` for the custom title (e.g. minimize/maximize). We know already that the custom title will not be present in the web.

Please find a way to move the custom title into `src/vs/workbench/electron-browser`. Feel free to create a new file `windowTitle.ts` along the existing `window.ts` there, or put everything into `window.ts`. 

This is something we should do rather soon, not late.

title: Workspace: add possibility to add read only folder
body: It would be nice to have possibility to add read only workspace folders for only referencing purpose. Specifically I am using GO language and sometimes I need to check its internal libraries. Adding library directory, does the job, but it is so easy to change something there and have so much problems that will be hard to detect. Making directory read only could solve the problem, but what if I want to reference one directory in one project and be able to edit it in other? This will start to be irritating...
